title: Your questions about the space-age Uno-X time trial helmet, answered
content:
Any eagle-eyed road racing fan no doubt took note of the wild new helmet on top of Uno-Xâ€™s racers at the recent Volta ao Algarve and Paris-Nice.

Even in an era where aero snoods and upturned breakfast bowl-shape lids are the norm, the Sweet Protection Redeemer 2Vi sure stands out. Itâ€™s got funky flared shoulders, an unusually straight back, and a weird hole on top.

So whatâ€™s the deal with the Darth Vader-design helmet thatâ€™s on its way to the Tour de France and Tour de France Femmes?

CyclingTips attended the helmetâ€™s official presentation and has the answers to (nearly all) your burning questions:

Errr â€¦ so how did this helmet come about?

The Redeemer is the latest development in the four-year partnership between Norway-based Sweet Protection and the Scandinavian Uno-X crew.

Formula 1 aerodynamicist Kyle Forster, Swedish brand Mips, and Uno-X racers SÃ¸ren WÃ¦renskjold and Joss Lowden all collaborated in what was a 15-month churn of computational fluid dynamics (CFD) analysis and wind tunnel testing.

The result?

A lid that representatives described as â€œreally, really fast and really, really safe.â€

Explain those big splayed shoulders?

Itâ€™s all about aero efficiency, duh.

Flaring out the shoulders smooths airflow over the whole body and prevents a blocking point.

â€œThe riderâ€™s shoulders have a very specific pressure pattern where they have a high-pressure region. The tighter you can get around the shoulders, the less uncontrolled losses youâ€™ll have coming out. And the less fluctuation and turbulence youâ€™ll have will result in slightly improved drag and improve downstream flow effects,â€ Forster explained in the launch event this week.

And the hole on top?

No, itâ€™s not a cooling duct.

Itâ€™s actually one of the Redeemerâ€™s most pioneering design points. The so-called â€œLaminar Flow Bypass Ductâ€ provides a passage for air to track from a riderâ€™s crown, through the shell of the helmet, and out of vents in the shoulders.

â€œThe pressure on the front of the helmet in the central area is reduced because weâ€™re allowing some mass flow to bleed through,â€ Forster said. â€œItâ€™s essentially as if we had a much smaller helmet in this region.â€

What other techy stuff do we need to know about it?

The helmet comes complete with an anti-fog visor thatâ€™s optimized for aerodynamics and integrates the industry-leading safety systems from Mips into its design.

The Redeemer includes a ribbed structure slated to help shock absorption and the innovative Mips â€œAir Nodeâ€ technology that reduces harmful rotational forces.

So in theory, itâ€™s as safe as it is fast.

It looks â€¦ unique, and social media kicked up a storm when it made its debut. What do the team and designers think of the reaction to its radical new lid?

Sweet Protection design chief Thomas Larsen RÃ¸ed said he was anticipating some uproar, and staff at Uno-X even saw the funny side.

But what counts, of course, is the performance.

â€œWhen you create something a bit radical, people are always going to come with guns blazing,â€ RÃ¸ed said. â€œThey can say whatever they want about it. But we know itâ€™s a fast helmet, and we know itâ€™s a safe helmet, so weâ€™re happy with it.â€

Is it as big as it looks?

Apparently not.

Weighing 490g including visor for a size large (size 59 â€“ 61) and around 450g for a medium (size 53 â€“ 58), itâ€™s on par with competition. And designers insist itâ€™s not the widest, longest, or tallest lid on the market, either.

Hereâ€™s the thing. Sweet Protection and Uno-X are adamant the Redeemer is one of the fastest in the bunch. But if you want numbers, youâ€™re not going to get any right now.

â€œPeople are tired of hearing about how many watts you save from this that and the other because itâ€™s so dependent on the protocol.
